entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German wint wind, Latin ventus, Greek aēnai to blow, Sanskrit vāti it blows

def.dt: :a natural movement of air of any velocity
:the earth's air or the gas surrounding a planet in natural motion horizontally
:an artificially produced movement of air
:solar wind stellar wind
:a destructive force or influence
:a force or agency that carries along or influences :tendency trend withstood the winds of popular opinion Felix Frankfurter
:breath 4a
:breath 2a
:the pit of the stomach :solar plexus
:gas generated in the stomach or the intestines pass wind
:compressed air or gas
:air
:something that is insubstantial: as
:mere talk :idle words
:nothing nothingness
:vain self-satisfaction
:air carrying a scent (as of a hunter or game)
:slight information especially about something secret :intimation got wind of the plan
:musical wind instruments especially as distinguished from strings and percussion
:players of wind instruments
:a direction from which the wind may blow :a point of the compass
:one of the cardinal points
:the direction from which the wind is blowing
:in the same direction as the main force of the wind
:as nearly as possible against the main force of the wind
:to be to windward of
:to be on the scent of
:to have a superior position to
:about to happen :astir afoot change is in the wind
:close to the wind
:close to a point of danger :near the permissible limit
:away from the direction from which the wind is blowing
:toward the direction from which the wind is blowing
:aside away threw caution to the wind
:to leeward
:in a place protected from the wind :under the lee
:to detect or follow by scent
:to expose to the air or wind :dry by exposing to air
:to make short of breath
:to regulate the wind supply of (an organ pipe)
:to rest (as a horse) in order to allow the breath to be recovered
:to scent game
:to pause for breath
:to cause (as a horn) to sound by blowing :blow
:to sound (as a call or note) on a horn wound a rousing call R. L. Stevenson
:to produce a sound on a horn

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English windan to twist, move with speed or force, brandish; akin to Old High German wintan to wind, Umbrian ohavendu let him turn aside

def.dt: :weave
:entangle involve
:to introduce sinuously or stealthily :insinuate
:to encircle or cover with something pliable :bind with loops or layers
:to turn completely or repeatedly about an object :coil twine
:to hoist or haul by means of a rope or chain and a windlass
:to move (a ship) by hauling on a capstan
:to tighten the spring of wind a clock
:to make tighter :tighten tune
:crank
:to raise to a high level (as of excitement or tension) usually used with up
:to cause to move in a curving line or path
:to turn the course of
:to lead (a person) as one wishes
:to cause (as a ship) to change direction :turn
:to turn (a ship) end for end
:to traverse on a curving course the river winds the valley
:to effect by or as if by curving
:bend warp
:to have a curving course or shape :extend in curves
:to proceed as if by winding
:to move so as to encircle something
:to turn when lying at anchor
:a mechanism (as a winch) for winding
:an act of winding :the state of being wound
:coil turn
:a particular method of winding
river W cen Wyoming, the upper course of Bighorn River
:wind chime usually used in plural
:a bell that is light enough to be moved and sounded by the wind
:carried by the wind wind–borne pollen wind–borne soil deposits
:affected with pulmonary emphysema or heaves
